body: Maybe you can provide only small repo to reproduce it?
unfortunately, no. I've tried but no matter how many interpolations I add it still doesn't deadlock. I think it has something to do with race conditions that only show up in a big project
Very very weird, maybe you can debug and provide source code of module?
This can only be caused by this.loadModule or this.importModule called by some loader.

yeah astroturf does this

https://github.com/4Catalyzer/astroturf/blob/386a73b8db290d6eb46ee61119b552b79c74d419/src/inline-loader.ts#L68

is there a workaround/tip for this case?
oh so this happens if some module gets loaded using both "normal" import and a loadModule/importModule through a loader "at the same time"?
is this something that can be addressed in webpack or is toss the responsibility of the library code?
is this something that can be addressed in webpack or is this the responsibility of the library code?
Will be great to report it to `astroturf `, we don't have special magic for `loadModule`

> is this something that can be addressed in webpack or is this the responsibility of the library code?

We can't do anything about that in webpack. We throw the error to make it easier to find the problem. Without the error this would lead to hanging builds, since the loader waits on it's on response.

i see. the most interesting thing is that if I remove this failsafe mechanism the build does not hang. that's why I thought a module blocking on itself was not a "real" blocker and can be removed

in any case, thanks for the info. I'll move this discussion to astroturf

issue.title: Fix incorrect BuildCycleError when loadModule() loads a module more than once

repository.name: webpack
repository.description: A bundler for javascript and friends. Packs many modules into a few bundled assets. Code Splitting allows for loading parts of the application on demand. Through "loaders", modules can be CommonJs, AMD, ES6 modules, CSS, Images, JSON, Coffeescript, LESS, ... and your custom stuff.

issue.body:
<!-- Thanks for submitting a pull request! Please provide enough information so that others can review your pull request. -->
<!-- Explain the **motivation** for making this change. What existing problem does the pull request solve? -->
<!-- Try to link to an open issue for more information. -->

This PR fixes #14379. 

There was a mistake in the module build cycle detection logic that made it incorrectly report a `BuildCycleError` when `LoaderContext.loadModule()` is used more than once for the same module (in certain situations).

Instead of tracking that a child module was being built by a parent, the `Compilation` was (mistakenly) always tracking that the parent was building itself. And modules were never unmarked on completion of their build. This had two notable effects:

1. Build cycles *were* prevented, because when an attempt was made to build a module twice, it was already marked as being built by itself, so a BuildCycleError was (correctly) reported.
2. Modules could not be requested twice (in a non-cyclic/valid way) via `LoaderContext.loadModule()`, due to 1.

Although point 2 has the caveat that modules are only affected if their loaders call `loadModule()`, and most modules don't, making this a somewhat rare occurrence.

<!-- In addition to that please answer these questions: -->

**What kind of change does this PR introduce?**

Bugfix.

<!-- E.g. a bugfix, feature, refactoring, build related change, etc -->

**Did you add tests for your changes?**

Yep. (The second commit adds a test which reproduces the issue and therefore fails. The commit after fixes the issue so the test passes.)

I wasn't able to run the whole test suite locally, but the `load-module-cycle` tests all passed.

<!-- Note that we won't merge your changes if you don't add tests -->

**Does this PR introduce a breaking change?**

<!-- If this PR introduces a breaking change, please describe the impact and a migration path for existing applications. -->

No.

**What needs to be documented once your changes are merged?**

<!-- List all the information that needs to be added to the documentation after merge -->
<!-- When your changes are merged you will be asked to contribute this to the documentation -->
I don't think anything needs documenting (other than the changelog), as this just brings webpack's behaviour in line with intended behaviour.

body: I also encountered `BuildCycleError` being incorrectly reported when porting a Webpack 4.x build to 5.x. I looked into it and found an error in the cycle tracking code which is fixed in the linked PR.
